fields.label_text:
ARMCHAIR
Oak.
ENGLISH; about 1625
W66.1950 gift of Brigadier W E Clark CMG DSO through the National Art-Collections Fund.
Large numbers of elaborately decorated armchairs of this type, with panelled backs and turned legs and arm-supports, were produced in the late 16th and 17th centuries. They were unusually described as ‘great chairs’ or ‘chairs of ease’ in contemporary inventories.

fields.physical_description: Armchair, carved and joined oak. The front legs in the form of fluted balusters with pseudo-Corinthian capitals. The rear legs of square section are prolonged to form the uprights. Four stretchers close to the ground. The arms, terminating in a scroll, supported on fluted balusters with pseudo-Ionic capitals. The back panel divided by applied mouldings with five geometrical compartments, decorated with flowers and point carved in low relief. The uprights surmounted by a pair of lion masks. The cresting compromises a ‘Tudor Rose’ flanked by reclining female figures.
fields.label:
ARMCHAIR
Oak.
ENGLISH; about 1625
W66.1950 gift of Brigadier W E Clark CMG DSO through the National Art-Collections Fund.
Large numbers of elaborately decorated armchairs of this type, with panelled backs and turned legs and arm-supports, were produced in the late 16th and 17th centuries. They were unusually described as ‘great chairs’ or ‘chairs of ease’ in contemporary inventories. [1/6/1989]
fields.bibliography:
Tobias Jellinek, Early British Chairs and Seats, 1500-1700 (Woodbridge, 2009), plate 88, page 93. English. Oak. Circa 1580 The back panel of this highly remarkable and exceptionally sophisticated armchair is an interesting geometric variation of the back panels of Plate 89 and 91. This time, though, the central motif is a lozenge containing a carved triad of daisies and is surrounded by four other panels, each with a different floral carving. The substantial horizontal arms with scroll ends have fine foliate carving along their sides. The arm supports are fluted columns with Corinthian capitals on cylindrical bases carved with ‘S’ motifs, and the legs are similar but with fish scales carved on their bases. A series of wild roses is carved along the seat rails and the seat edge has narrow rope carving. The stretchers are carved with a chain motif with two simple scratch-mouldings on the top edge. Note particularly the carving on both sides of the squares on either side of the front rail, the applied lion masks on the top rail, the carnation and pomegranates on the rail itself and the cockerels’ head on the upper end of the ‘ears’. Last, but not least, note the amazing crest depicting two scantily clad women leaning casually against a delicately carved Tudor rose with a turned and carved finial. This crest bears a curious similarity to the crests on the two armchairs from Salisbury, Plates 110 and 111.
English. Circa 1580
See Country Life, Sept. 28th 1935, pp. 320-21 About 1620. 'This chair is in remarkable condition, its only restoration being the small finial above the Tudor rose.'
WINDISCH-GRAETZ, Franz: Möbel Europa. 2. Renaissance-Manierismus (Munich, 1982), no. 239
fields.credit: Given by Brigadier W. E. Clark CMG, DSO
fields.history_note: Given by Brigadier W.E.Clark, C.M.G., D.S.O, through the National Art Collections Fund
